Because the application uses the GPS, which can vary in accuracy, the user has to build a certain amount of experience to judge what trust to put into the measured distances and areas. To help with this, two estimated upper bounds for the error of the current measured area is given here. The left value assumes a GPS accuracy of 1 m (approximately 1 yd), while the right assumes an accuracy of 10m (approximately 10 yd). Note that if the experienced accuracy of the GPS is any of these values, the error should actually be very much smaller than the estimate, because the errors tend to average out. Especially for larger areas.

If your main interest is in distances of straight paths, these should be measure in manual mode as the "wiggling" along the path otherwise will add up to yield too large values for the measured distances. For meter accuracy in the GPS signal, these "wigglings" does to my experience however not affect the result to more than a few percent in automatic mode.

It can take some time before the application receives GPS signal and is able to begin a measurement. Be aware that it is very rare that GPS signal is received while being indoor.


Also be aware that the application not is very accurate for room size areas, but it become increasingly accurate as the measured area is getting larger. Some help with estimating the error in the measurement is provided under the "Error estimate"-option in the menu. However, these estimates are probably way to large in almost all cases, and the accuracy much better than those. More information on this is found in the actual "Error estimate"-dialog.

All controls that relates to the actual measurement are displayed at the top of the main view. The two first drop down menus are used to specify which units are used for the measurement. The units can be changed at any moment and it is in this way possible to convert between different units during as well as after a measurement.


The rightmost drop down menu allows you to specify weather logging should be done automatically or manually. The automatic mode is recommended for most area measurements, but to measure the distance between two points, use the manual mode to get the best precision. The manual mode can also be useful for area measurement whenever obstacles prevents the actual outline of the area to be traversed. In these cases, turn on the manual mode, take whatever path that is needed to get around the obstacle, and then return to the automatic mode to continue the measurement.


The three buttons on the second line are used to start, stop and reset a measurement, as well as to manually log coordinates while in manual mode.


To be able to make a measurement, the application has to be in "measure mode". The other mode the application can be in is "view mode", and this is indicated by the dot in the top left corner being blue. To change from "view mode" to "measure mode", choose "Measure" from the menu.
Measured areas can be saved internally and later viewed in the application. The save, view and delete options in the menu are used to handle such files.\n

Files can be imported and exported from the application to either be used with other softwares such as Google earth or maps, or by another "Distance and area measurement"-application. This is done with the import and export options in the menu. In order to view the areas in other compatible software, export the files as .kml-files. But to transfer them and import them into another "Distance and area measurement"-application, use the .damef-format.


To import a .damef-file on another phone the files must manually be placed into the folder "/Android/data/Distance and area measurement/" on that phones external memory, and then imported with the import option.


Similarly, to access exported .kml-files, connect the phone to a computer and access the files in the folder "/Android/data/Distance and area measurement/".


Feel free to contact me if this explanation not makes sense to you. Contact information can be found under the menu option "Mutual support".
 [An even better solution might be to ask your kids for help. If you do not have any, make sure you do get some. You will not survive an ever technology evolving future without them! ;) ]


Only files produced with v1.11 or later will produce sensible .kml-files.

Save as .kml to be able to view the files in Google earth or maps.\nSave as .damef to transfer files to another \"Distance and area measurement\"-application.\nAll files will be saved in the folder \"/Android/data/Distance and area measurement/\" on the external memory.
